questions.text: Where in the tubule would a patient with severe central diabetes insipidus have the lowest tubular fluid osmolality?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Stepwise Reasoning

 

  1. Central Diabetes Insipidus (DI):
    • ADH is absent.
    • Collecting ducts become impermeable to water.
    • No water reabsorption occurs in collecting ducts.
    • Urine becomes maximally dilute (hypo-osmotic).
  2. Tubular fluid osmolality along nephron in DI:
    • Proximal tubule (A): isotonic (~300 mOsm/L).
    • Descending limb: hypertonic (water leaves, solutes retained).
    • Ascending limb (B, C): impermeable to water, NaCl reabsorbed → tubular fluid becomes progressively hypotonic (~100 mOsm/L).
    • Collecting duct (D):
      • Normally, ADH makes it permeable → water reabsorbed, urine concentrated.
      • In central DI, no ADH → remains impermeable → tubular fluid becomes even more dilute (as low as 50–70 mOsm/L).
  3. Lowest osmolality site:
    → Collecting duct (D) in the absence of ADH.

questions.text:
Which of the following are reduced in Iron Deficiency Anemia?

 

  1. Ferritin
  2. TIBC
  3. Transferrin saturation
  4. RDW
  5. Hepcidin 
  6. Soluble transferrin receptor
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 5

 

In Iron Deficiency Anemia (IDA), the following changes are typically observed:

 

  1. Ferritin: Reduced — Ferritin is the storage form of iron, and its levels decrease in IDA because the body's iron stores are depleted.
  2. TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity): Increased — TIBC increases as the body produces more transferrin to maximize iron binding and transport when iron is low.
  3. Transferrin Saturation: Reduced — Since there is less iron to bind, the percentage of transferrin saturated with iron decreases.
  4. RDW (Red Cell Distribution Width): Increased — RDW is increased due to variation in red blood cell size caused by iron deficiency.
  5. Hepcidin: Reduced — Hepcidin, which inhibits iron absorption, is decreased in IDA to promote more iron absorption from the gut.
  6. Soluble Transferrin Receptor: Increased — Elevated in IDA because cells upregulate transferrin receptors to capture more iron.

 

Thus, the parameters that are reduced in Iron Deficiency Anemia are:

 

  • Ferritin (1)
  • Transferrin Saturation (3)
  • Hepcidin (5)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after developing sudden-onset right-side weakness and difficulty speaking. He has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and has been taking warfarin for the past several years with a stable prothrombin time. His wife adds that he started taking a new drug 2 weeks ago, but she does not remember its name. Transesophageal echocardiogram reveals a small thrombus in the left atrium. This patient most likely started taking which of the following drugs recently?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) St John's wort

 

Warfarin is metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes.

 

  • St John’s wort is a potent CYP450 inducer, which increases the metabolism of warfarin → decreases its plasma levels → reduces anticoagulant effect → increased risk of thromboembolism (like this patient’s atrial thrombus and stroke).

 

Other Options:


Option A. Amiodarone: CYP450 inhibitor → increases warfarin effect → ↑ risk of bleeding, not clotting.


Option B. Cimetidine: CYP450 inhibitor → increases warfarin levels → ↑ bleeding risk.


Option C. Ciprofloxacin: also inhibits CYP450 → ↑ warfarin effect and bleeding tendency.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about proto-oncogenes? 

 

  1. KIT has increased expression in GIST.
  2. KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.
  3. ERBB2 over-expression is associated with breast carcinomas.
  4. PDGFR-β has suppressed expression in colorectal cancers.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 3

 

  • 1. KIT has increased expression in GIST: True; KIT (CD117) mutations drive gastrointestinal stromal tumors.
  • 3. ERBB2 over-expression is associated with breast carcinomas: True; HER2/neu (ERBB2) amplification promotes breast cancer progression.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

  • 2. KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung carcinoma: False; KRAS mutations are more common in non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC).
  • 4. PDGFR-β has suppressed expression in colorectal cancers: False; PDGFR-β is often overexpressed in certain cancers, not specifically suppressed in colorectal cancer.

choices.text: The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle.

questions.text: Regarding the procedure done with the needle shown below, which of the following is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coagulopathy is not a contraindication

 

  • This is false. Coagulopathy is an absolute contraindication to lumbar puncture.
  • Spinal or epidural hematoma may occur, causing cord compression and permanent paralysis.
  • Hence, coagulation profile (platelet count, PT/INR) should always be checked before the procedure.
  • A platelet count of ≥50,000/µL is generally considered the safe minimum threshold.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Done in lateral recumbent position: Correct. Standard position is lateral recumbent with knees flexed, allowing proper vertebral alignment and accurate CSF pressure measurement.

 

Option B. Breath holding not necessary: Correct. LP is performed in the lumbar region, so respiratory motion has no effect; {unlike thoracocentesis}, no breath control is required.

 

Option C. The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle: Correct. Keeping the bevel parallel to dural fibers minimizes tissue trauma and reduces the risks of CSF leak and post-LP headache.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with sudden-onset palpitations and lightheadedness while playing video games. He states this has occurred intermittently over the past year, but the episodes typically resolve spontaneously after a few minutes. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. ECG is shown below. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Ectopic ventricular pacemaker activity

choices.text: Iodide uptake by the thyroid gland
Peripheral conversion of T4 to T3

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of weight loss, heat intolerance, palpitations, and insomnia over the past 4 months. Her vital signs are blood pressure 140/85 mm Hg, pulse 110/min, and regular. On examination, the thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and non-tender. Laboratory studies reveal decreased serum TSH and elevated free thyroxine (T4) levels. Methimazole is initiated as treatment. Which of the following processes is most likely inhibited by this treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coupling of iodotyrosine

 

Methimazole inhibits thyroid peroxidase, preventing the coupling of iodotyrosines to form T3 and T4, thereby reducing thyroid hormone synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iodide uptake by the thyroid gland: Methimazole does not inhibit iodide uptake; that is the function of the sodium-iodide symporter.

 

Option C. Peripheral conversion of T4 to T3: It does not affect peripheral conversion of T4 to T3; drugs like propranolol or amiodarone influence that.

 

Option D. Colloid production: Colloid production is not directly affected by methimazole.

questions.text: You work under a research scientist who is working on determining the association of adenocarcinoma of pancreas with a compound X. He uses a test whose steps are shown in the image below to determine the mutagenic effect and potential carcinogenicity of compound X. What is this test that he has used?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ames test

 

The image shows the classic Ames test, which is used to assess the mutagenic and carcinogenic potential of a compound by observing its ability to induce genetic mutations in a strain of Salmonella that requires histidine for growth. An increased number of revertant colonies (his- to his+) after exposure to the compound, especially compared to the control, indicates that the compound X may cause mutations.

 

Other Option:


Option A. CGH (Comparative Genomic Hybridization): detects genomic abnormalities, not mutagenicity.


Option B. Micro nucleus test: evaluates chromosomal damage, not point mutations in bacteria.


Option C. Microtox bio-assay: measures toxicity using bioluminescent bacteria, not mutagenicity.

questions.text:
Many GPCR receptors act via an increase in cAMP. The steps involved in this mechanism are given below. Which of the following is the correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway?

 

  1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
  2. Activation of PKA
  3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
  4. Phosphorylation of target proteins
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 2 and 4

 

Upon ligand binding, the GPCR activates adenylate cyclase, which converts ATP to cAMP. cAMP then activates protein kinase A (PKA), which phosphorylates target proteins to produce cellular effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incorrect sequence: PKA cannot activate before cAMP formation.

 

Option C. Phosphorylation occurs after PKA activation, not before.

 

Option D. This order is completely reversed and physiologically incorrect.

questions.text: The flow volume curve after spirometry in patient 1 is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morbid obesity

 

Morbid obesity causes a restrictive pattern on spirometry characterized by reduced lung volumes with preserved flow rates, resulting in a flow-volume curve with decreased volumes but relatively normal shape, consistent with restriction rather than obstruction.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Vocal cord palsy: Typically produces variable extrathoracic obstruction with flattening of the inspiratory limb on flow-volume curve.

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: Shows obstructive pattern with reduced expiratory flow and scooped-out appearance of the curve.

 

Option D. Emphysema: An obstructive pattern characterized by reduced flow rates and increased lung volumes with a concave expiratory limb.

Physical examination shows vital signs with temperature 37°C, pulse 88/min, respiratory rate 18/min, and blood pressure 85/60 mmHg. The fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) is <1%. Which of the following underlying conditions is he most likely to have?

questions.text: Identify the drug pharmacokinetics from the graph:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) First order kinetics 

 

The graph shows a linear relationship between rate of elimination and drug concentration. This is characteristic of first order kinetics, where a constant proportion of the drug is eliminated per unit time, and the rate depends directly on the drug concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zero order kinetics: The rate of elimination is constant regardless of the drug concentration (graph shows a horizontal line), seen in drugs like phenytoin and ethanol when their elimination pathways are saturated.

 

Option C. Second order kinetics: Relates to reactions where the rate depends on the square of the concentration of one reactant or on two different reactants, not typically used for drug elimination graphs in pharmacokinetics.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and CT is shown below. What would be your next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous thrombolysis

 

  •  The patient has acute ischemic stroke (left-sided facial weakness, <4.5 hours, CT shows no bleed). IV thrombolysis is the treatment of choice if no contraindications.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. CT angiogram: Useful for large vessel occlusion planning (thrombectomy) but not the immediate next step if thrombolysis window is open.


Option B. Start on aspirin + clopidogrel: Antiplatelet therapy is started if outside the thrombolysis window or after thrombolysis, not the immediate first step.


Option D. IV Labetalol: Used for BP control if systolic >185 or diastolic >110 mmHg before thrombolysis; here, BP is 160/100, so not needed now.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has the same underlying pathophysiology as the mechanism of action of Eptifibatide?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Glanzmann thrombasthenia

questions.text: Match the following with types of hypersensitivity:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

  1. A 38-year-old female with double vision and mass in the mediastinum: Type 2 hypersensitivity (B) (Myasthenia gravis—antibody-mediated against acetylcholine receptors)
  2. Graft kidney showing mononuclear cell infiltrates with C4d deposition in peritubular capillaries on IF: Type 2 hypersensitivity (B) (Hyperacute and acute humoral rejection—antibody mediated with complement activation)
  3. Renal biopsy in a patient with SLE presenting with hematuria shows thickened vessel walls with pink-staining material
     → Type 3 hypersensitivity (C)
     (Immune complex-mediated—SLE nephritis)
  4. Casoni test in a patient with hydatid cyst: Type 1 hypersensitivity (A) (Skin test—immediate hypersensitivity reaction)

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

 

DKA is diagnosed with hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis (pH <7.3), and elevated anion gap. Serum potassium is usually normal or elevated initially due to insulin deficiency and acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S. glucose > 250 mg/Dl: Glucose >250 mg/dL is a standard criterion for DKA.

 

Option B. Arterial pH < 7.3: pH <7.3 indicates metabolic acidosis.

 

Option C. Anion gap > 12: Anion gap >12 confirms high-anion-gap metabolic acidosis.

choices.text: Donor T cells in the graft

questions.text: Two weeks after undergoing allogeneic stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma, a 55-year-old man develops a severely pruritic rash, abdominal cramps, and profuse diarrhea. He appears lethargic. Physical examination shows yellow sclerae. There is a generalized maculopapular rash on his face, trunk, and lower extremities, and desquamation of both soles. His serum alanine aminotransferase is 115 U/L, serum aspartate aminotransferase is 97 U/L, and serum total bilirubin is 2.7 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Donor T cells in the graft

 

Clinical scenario: Patient develops rash, diarrhoea, jaundice, and liver enzyme elevation 2 weeks post–allogeneic stem cell transplant → classic for acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

 

  • Mechanism: Donor T cells in the graft recognize recipient (host) antigens as foreign and mount an immune attack against host tissues (skin, liver, GI tract).

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Newly formed anti-HLA antibodies: Seen in graft rejection, not GVHD.

 

Option C. Proliferating transplanted B cells: May cause post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (EBV-related), not GVHD.

 

Option D. Activated recipient T cells: Would mediate host-versus-graft rejection, but here the host marrow has been ablated.

questions.text: A 41-year-old male patient presented with a sudden onset of severe headache and vomiting. On examination, marked neck rigidity was noted. LP was done which reveals findings as shown in the image. Which among the following drugs is ideal for preventing delayed cerebral ischemia in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Nimodipine

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to confusion, abdominal pain, and vomiting for the past two days. Her parents report that she has been excessively thirsty and urinating frequently over the last few weeks. On examination, her vital signs are as follows: temperature 37.2°C (99°F), pulse 110/min, blood pressure 90/60 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 28/min. Laboratory investigations reveal the following:

 

  • Glucose 320 mg/dL
  • Sodium 132 meq/l
  • Potassium 5.2 meq/l
  • Bicarbonate 12 meq/l
  • Arterial pH 7.25
  • Urinalysis: Positive for urine and ketones

 

Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the development of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Islet leukocytic infiltration

 

This patient has type 1 diabetes with DKA, where autoimmune islet leukocytic infiltration destroys beta cells, leading to insulin deficiency and ketosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive caloric intake does not directly cause DKA.

 

Option B. HLA polymorphisms increase susceptibility but are not the direct cause of acute DKA.

 

Option C. Beta-cell amyloid deposition is associated with type 2 diabetes, not type 1.

questions.text: The image below demonstrates normal lung volumes and capacities. Which of the following changes is unlikely in a “pink puffer”?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1+2+3 is decreased

 

In a “pink puffer” (emphysema dominant COPD), total lung capacity (1+2+3) is not decreased; rather, it is typically increased due to air trapping and hyperinflation. Options A, C, and D describe findings consistent with emphysema (increased residual volume, increased FRC, and decreased vital capacity with inspiratory reserve volume).

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. 2 is increased: Functional residual capacity (FRC) is increased in pink puffers.

 

Option C. 5 is increased: Residual volume (RV) is increased due to air trapping.

 

Option C. 1+3+4 is decreased: Inspiratory and expiratory reserve volumes and vital capacity (inspiratory reserve + tidal + expiratory reserve) are decreased due to hyperinflation.

choices.text: It is the only heat stable antibody
Levels are raised in helminthic infections
It does not pass the placental barrier
It has a half-life of 1-5 days

questions.text: Casoni reaction is seen in patients with hydatid cyst. Which of the following is incorrect about the immunoglobulin causing this reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is the only heat stable antibody

 

The antibody involved is IgE, which is heat labile, not heat stable.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Levels are raised in helminthic infections: IgE levels increase during parasitic infections.

 

Option C. It does not pass the placental barrier: IgE cannot cross the placenta.

 

Option D. It has a half-life of 1-5 days: IgE has a short half-life of about 1–2 days in circulation.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. In nutmeg liver, dark areas represent necrosis due to passive congestion, and white areas represent viable liver tissue.
  2. Sirtuins are a family of seven histone deacetylases involved in increasing insulin sensitivity. 
  3. Long-term hemodialysis patients with renal failure lead to development of amyloidosis due to the accumulation of Aβ2-microglobulin.
  4. Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulability.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

All statements are correct

 

1. In nutmeg liver, dark areas represent necrosis due to passive congestion, and white areas represent viable liver tissue: Dark areas = congested/necrotic, pale areas = viable tissue.

 

2. Sirtuins are a family of seven histone deacetylases involved in increasing insulin sensitivity: Histone deacetylases that improve insulin sensitivity and metabolic regulation.

 

3. Long-term hemodialysis patients with renal failure lead to development of amyloidosis due to the accumulation of Aβ2-microglobulin: Complication of long-term hemodialysis.

 

4. Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulability: Most common genetic hypercoagulable disorder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient has NYHA class III heart failure, with dyspnea, pedal edema and K+ levels of 5.5mg% and creatinine 1.1 mg%. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Furosemide

 

  • The patient has NYHA class III heart failure with signs of congestion (dyspnea, pedal edema).
  • Elevated potassium (5.5 mg%) indicates hyperkalemia, which contraindicates or limits the use of drugs that increase potassium levels, such as:
    • Spironolactone (potassium-sparing diuretic)
    • Enalapril (ACE inhibitor causes potassium retention)
  • Digoxin is used cautiously and does not address volume overload.
  • Furosemide (a loop diuretic) effectively reduces fluid overload and does not increase potassium levels; it can help reduce symptoms without worsening hyperkalemia.

 

Thus, furosemide is the safest choice for this patient with heart failure and hyperkalemia.

choices.text: CD14 on macrophages with bacterial lipopolysaccharide
CD16 on NK cells with IgG-coated infected cells
CD18 on neutrophils with ICAM-1 on endothelial cells
CD28 on T lymphocytes with CD80/86 on epidermal dendritic cells

questions.text: A 28-year-old medical student undergoes a tuberculin skin test (TST) as part of a routine health check. He is asymptomatic with no history of recent fever, weight loss, or cough. He receives an intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD) on the inner surface of his forearm. After 48 hours, a raised, erythematous induration measuring 18 mm is observed at the injection site. Which of the following interactions is critical to the development of this patient’s skin reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CD28 on T lymphocytes with CD80/86 on epidermal dendritic cells

 

The TST is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction mediated by CD4+ T-cells. Interaction of CD28 on T-cells with CD80/86 on antigen-presenting dendritic cells provides the costimulatory signal essential for T-cell activation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. CD14 on macrophages with bacterial lipopolysaccharide: Involved in innate immune response to Gram-negative bacteria, not delayed-type hypersensitivity.

 

Option B. CD16 on NK cells with IgG-coated infected cells: Mediates antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC), not TST reaction.

 

Option C. CD18 on neutrophils with ICAM-1 on endothelial cells: Involved in leukocyte adhesion and migration, not the critical T-cell activation in TST.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented with rapidly progressing, symmetrical muscle weakness, starting in the legs. Which of the following is not a treatment option in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Steroids

choices.text: Inability to produce beta globin chains
Persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for history of multiple episodes of acute bony pain as well as sudden transient chest pain. Peripheral blood smear with Wright stain is shown. This patient's PBS are most likely related to which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman comes to the AIIMS OPD due to a 6.8-kg weight gain over the last few months. The patient also has experienced weakness and cannot lift weights that she was able to lift before the onset of her symptoms. On examination, blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and pulse is 88/min and regular. Neurologic examination shows proximal muscle weakness. Dark terminal hair is present on the lower abdomen. Fasting laboratory results are as follows: 

 

Sodium-142 mEq/L

Potassium-3.6 mEq/L

Chloride-98 mEq/L

Bicarbonate-28 mEq/L

Calcium-9.2 mg/dL

TSH-2.2 mlU/L (N-0.5 to 5.0 mIU/L)

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Overnight low-dose dexamethasone suppression test

 

The patient has features suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome (weight gain, hypertension, proximal muscle weakness, and hirsutism). The overnight low-dose dexamethasone suppression test is the first-line screening test to confirm endogenous cortisol excess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early-morning cortisol level: Early-morning cortisol can vary and is less sensitive for screening Cushing’s syndrome.

 

Option C. Serum ACTH level: Serum ACTH is useful after confirming hypercortisolism to differentiate ACTH-dependent vs independent causes.

 

Option D. Cosyntropin test: Cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test is mainly used to evaluate adrenal insufficiency, not Cushing’s.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Syndrome Z in a 45-year old Indian man?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Waist circumference of 88cm

 

  • Syndrome Z refers to the coexistence of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) with metabolic syndrome.
  • Metabolic syndrome components include:
    • Elevated blood pressure (≥130/85 mm Hg or on treatment)
    • High fasting triglycerides (≥150 mg/dL)
    • Increased waist circumference (for South Asians, cutoff is typically ≥90 cm for men)
  • This patient has blood pressure of 145/89 mm Hg and triglycerides of 160 mg/dL, both fitting the criteria.
  • Waist circumference of 88 cm is below the typical cutoff for Indian men, so this is not a component meeting the criteria.

 

Therefore, waist circumference of 88 cm is not a component of Syndrome Z in this patient.The correct answer is C) Waist circumference of 88 cm.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections and Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia. The flowcytometry analysis of the boy (Boxes c & d) is shown below (Boxes a & b are normal). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyper IgM syndrome 

 

The flow cytometry analysis shows that the patient (boxes c & d) has normal numbers of B cells (CD19+) as seen in box c, but box d reveals a significant reduction or absence of CD40 ligand (CD40L) expression on T cells. This pattern is typical of Hyper IgM syndrome, an immunodeficiency caused by a defect in CD40L, preventing class switching of immunoglobulins. Patients present with recurrent bacterial infections and opportunistic infections like Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia due to impaired humoral and cell-mediated immunity.

 

Other Option:
 

Option A. Bare lymphocytes: Bare lymphocyte syndrome presents with combined immunodeficiency due to lack of MHC molecules and would show decreased B and T cells.
 

Option B. Chronic granulocyte deficiency: Chronic granulocyte deficiency affects neutrophils and not lymphocyte populations.
 

Option D. DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome involves T cell deficiency due to thymic hypoplasia, not B cell or CD40L abnormalities.

questions.text: All of the following are the part of the innate immunity except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B lymphocytes 

 

B lymphocytes are part of the adaptive immune system, producing antigen-specific antibodies after activation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Alpha defensins:Antimicrobial peptides that provide immediate defense against pathogens.

 

Option C. Gamma Delta T lymphocytes: Bridge innate and adaptive immunity; respond rapidly to non-peptide antigens.

 

Option D. Lectin pathway: A complement activation pathway of innate immunity.

questions.text: All of the factors would suggest a higher risk for a patient with TIA developing stroke in the future according to ABCD2 scoring except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duration of symptoms 5 mins

 

  • In ABCD2 scoring, TIA duration <10 minutes does not add any points, so it does not increase stroke risk.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Age 65 years: Age ≥60 years gives 1 point, increasing risk.


Option C. BP 140/90 mmHg: Hypertension at presentation gives 1 point.


Option D. Diabetes: Presence of diabetes adds 1 point, raising stroke risk.

questions.text: Identify the malignancy:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Adult T cell leukemia

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with asymmetric sensory loss in the right leg and skin lesions as shown below. Lab evaluation reveals eosinophilia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans C) Churg Strauss syndrome

questions.text:
Arrange the following sentences in the correct order for activation of B cells.

 

  1. T-helper cells interact with the presented antigen peptides.
  2. Improved quality of the immune response with affinity maturation.
  3. Somatic hypermutation and immunoglobulin isotype class switching occur.
  4. Antigen binding to B cell receptor.
  5. Binding of CD40 ligand on T cells to CD 40 on B cells.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4, 1, 5, 3, 2 

 

  • 4. Antigen binding to B cell receptor: B cell recognizes the antigen.
  • 1. T-helper cells interact with the presented antigen peptides: B cell presents antigen to T-helper cell.
  • 5. Binding of CD40 ligand on T cells to CD40 on B cells: Provides costimulatory signal for B-cell activation.
  • 3. Somatic hypermutation and immunoglobulin isotype class switching occur: → Enhances antibody diversity and function.
  • 2. Improved quality of the immune response with affinity maturation: Produces high-affinity antibodies.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo, diplopia, hoarseness, dysphagia and left Horner's syndrome associated with numbness of the left face and right-side limbs. Which artery is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery 

 

  •  The findings describe Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome, classically caused by PICA infarction → ipsilateral Horner’s, facial sensory loss, contralateral body sensory loss, and bulbar symptoms.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option B. Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA): Causes lateral pontine syndrome (facial paralysis, hearing loss, vertigo), not the classic Wallenberg picture.


Option C. Superior cerebellar artery: Infarction produces ipsilateral ataxia and cerebellar signs, not bulbar cranial nerve involvement.


Option D. Basilar artery: Large infarcts here cause “locked-in” syndrome with quadriplegia, not the lateral medullary syndrome described.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major diagnostic criterion of neuromyelitis Optica?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Anti-Aq2 IgG antibody

questions.text:
What characteristics define necrosis among the options provided? 

 

  1. Disrupted cell membrane
  2. Induces inflammation
  3. Swelling of the cell
  4. Can be seen physiologically
  5. Causes nuclear fragmentation
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 

 

  • 1. Disrupted cell membrane: Necrotic cells lose membrane integrity.
  • 2. Induces inflammation: Necrosis releases intracellular contents, triggering inflammatory response.
  • 3. Swelling of the cell: Necrotic cells often swell (oncosis) before lysis.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

  • 4. Can be seen physiologically: False; necrosis is pathological, not physiological.
  • 5. Causes nuclear fragmentation: More characteristic of apoptosis, not typical necrosis.

choices.text: Blood received from blood bank should be completely transfused within 4 hours of receiving
Calcium can be added to the blood product to prevent hypocalcemia
Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction may present in first 24hrs

questions.text: All of the following are the correct statements about Blood transfusion except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Calcium can be added to the blood product to prevent hypocalcemia

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy has frequent episodes of facial edema around his lips. It usually occurs after an emotional stressor. He also has a family history of similar conditions. Which of the following is the main mediator of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bradykinin

 

The patient likely has hereditary angioedema, where bradykinin is the main mediator causing vascular permeability and swelling.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Leukotriene: Involved in allergic reactions and asthma, not hereditary angioedema.

 

Option C. Prostaglandin E2: Mediates fever and inflammation, not primary in angioedema.

 

Option D. Histamine: Responsible for allergic urticaria, not bradykinin-mediated hereditary angioedema.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the bradycardia seen in Cushing reflex?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Baroreceptor activation 

 

  • The Cushing reflex occurs in response to increased intracranial pressure (ICP), which leads to cerebral ischemia.
  • Increased ICP causes a sympathetic surge to raise blood pressure (hypertension) to maintain cerebral perfusion.
  • The elevated blood pressure activates the baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch.
  • Baroreceptor activation triggers a reflex parasympathetic response, leading to bradycardia despite the sympathetic drive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heart failure: Not related to Cushing reflex bradycardia.

 

Option C. Cardiac conduction defect: Not relevant to this reflex.

 

Option D. Increased activity of RVLM (rostral ventrolateral medulla): RVLM mediates sympathetic outflow causing hypertension and tachycardia, not bradycardia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure is 165/92 mm Hg on the left arm and 162/90 mm Hg on the right arm. He reports that he is adherent with his medication and exercise regimen. The physician adds a drug to his antihypertensive medication regimen. This drug increases serum renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels, and decreases serum aldosterone levels, without affecting bradykinin levels. Which of the following drugs was most likely added to this patient's medication regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candesartan

 

  • The drug described increases serum renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels but decreases aldosterone levels without affecting bradykinin.
  • Candesartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB). ARBs block the angiotensin II receptor, leading to decreased aldosterone production.
  • Because they block the receptor but not the production of angiotensin II, levels of renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II increase due to feedback.
  • ARBs do not inhibit bradykinin breakdown, so bradykinin levels remain unchanged.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aliskiren: Direct renin inhibitor; lowers renin and downstream angiotensins.

 

Option C. Verapamil: Calcium channel blocker; does not affect renin-angiotensin system.

 

Option D. Lisinopril: ACE inhibitor; increases bradykinin levels by blocking its degradation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient with class II pulmonary hypertension presents with a positive vasoreactivity test. Which of the following is used in the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nifedipine

 

Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, is the first-line treatment for patients with pulmonary hypertension who have a positive vasoreactivity response. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Iloprost: Used as a prostacyclin analog for severe cases, not initial therapy after a positive vasoreactivity test. 

 

Option B. Ambrisentan: An endothelin receptor antagonist used for pulmonary hypertension but not first for vasoreactive patients. 

 

Option D. Epoprostenol: Reserved for advanced pulmonary hypertension refractory to other treatments.

choices.text: Blockade of presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels
Blockade of presynaptic voltage-gated sodium channels
Inhibition of vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to recurrent, generalized tonic-clonic seizures over the past 24 hours. He takes no medications and has no family history of epilepsy. The patient's temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 10/min. During the examination, the patient suddenly develops sustained, generalized tonic-clonic convulsions without fully regaining consciousness between episodes. Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of the most appropriate initial therapy for his seizures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enhanced postsynaptic chloride influx

 

  • The initial therapy for ongoing generalized tonic–clonic seizures/status epilepticus in a child is a benzodiazepine (eg, IV lorazepam or IM midazolam), which potentiates GABA-A receptors

choices.text: 10% of the normal population can have epileptiform discharges.
Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy.
Doing EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves.

questions.text: True about electroencephalogram (EEG) is all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 10% of the normal population can have epileptiform discharges.

 

  •  Only about 1% of healthy individuals may show epileptiform discharges; 10% is an overestimation, hence incorrect.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option B. Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy: True, though sometimes challenging due to deep seizure foci, scalp EEG can still provide useful localization.


Option C. Doing EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures: Correct, seizures are primarily a clinical diagnosis; EEG supports but is not always required.


Option D. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves: True, diffuse slowing and triphasic waves can be seen in metabolic and infectious encephalopathies like PML.

questions.text: What is the route of dissemination of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hematogeneous

 

The lung specimen shows multiple millet-sized nodules throughout the parenchyma, classic for miliary tuberculosis. This pattern results from hematogenous dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, spreading the infection widely via the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Air-borne: Airborne transmission is the mode of initial infection, not the cause of disseminated miliary disease.

 

Option B. Feco-oral: Not applicable for tuberculosis or miliary spread.

 

Option C. Droplet: Droplet transmission applies to some respiratory infections but not the disseminated spread of tuberculosis.

choices.text: Angiotensin II on vascular smooth muscle and Vasopressin via V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle
Angiotensin Il on vascular smooth muscle and Vasopressin via V2 receptor on epithelial cells
Angiotensin II on epithelial cells and Vasopressin via V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle
Angiotensin II on epithelial cells and Vasopressin via V2 receptor on epithelial cells

questions.text: Which of the following act via the IP3-DAG Messenger System?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Angiotensin II on vascular smooth muscle and Vasopressin via V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle

 

Angiotensin II (AT1 receptor) and vasopressin via V1 receptor activate the IP3-DAG pathway, leading to calcium release and smooth muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Angiotensin II on vascular smooth muscle and Vasopressin via V2 receptor on epithelial cells: Vasopressin via V2 receptor works through cAMP, not IP3-DAG.

 

Option C. Angiotensin II on epithelial cells and Vasopressin via V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle: Angiotensin II does not act on epithelial cells for IP3-DAG signaling.

 

Option D. Angiotensin II on epithelial cells and Vasopressin via V2 receptor on epithelial cells: Both act on epithelial cells or V2 receptor via cAMP, not IP3-DAG.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with chest pain and shortness of breath. An ECG was taken in the emergency and was shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior MI

 

The patient's ECG shows classic signs of a posterior myocardial infarction (MI). The characteristic features of posterior MI in leads V1, V2 and (±) V3 include a tall R wave, ST depression, and upright T wave. These features suggest a mirror image of an infarction in the posterior wall of the left ventricle. While definitive diagnosis of a posterior MI typically involves additional leads (V7, V8, V9), the observed patterns in leads V2 and V3 are indicative of this condition.

 

In the provided case, the absence of ST elevation rules out an acute STEMI. NSTEMI and unstable angina can only be differentiated by cardiac biomarkers such as troponins, which are not mentioned here. Acute myocarditis would typically present with non-specific ECG changes and a relevant clinical history, such as a recent viral infection, which is not present in this scenario.

 

  • The ECG shows:
    • ST segment depression in leads V1 to V3
    • Tall, broad R waves in V1–V3
    • Upright T waves in these leads

 

This pattern is the mirror image (reciprocal changes) of ST elevation MI seen in the posterior wall, as the standard precordial leads (V1–V3) "look through" the anterior wall. Posterior MI does not directly produce ST elevation on the standard 12-lead ECG, but instead these characteristic reciprocal changes.

 

  • NSTEMI and unstable angina may show ST depression or T wave changes but do not have prominent R waves in V1–V3.
  • Acute myocarditis can mimic MI but seldom presents with this classic pattern.

 

Thus, the ECG is diagnostic of a posterior myocardial infarction (MI).

questions.text: Which technique is used to identify tissue bound auto-antibodies?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Direct immunofluorescence

questions.solution: Ans. D) Associated WPW syndrome

choices.text: A high-protein diet increases the kidneys ability to concentrate urine
High vasopressin increases the urea deposition in the medullary interstitium
Urea is transported by urea transport proteins (UT-A) by primary active transport
Helpful in creation of counter current mechanism

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the role of urea in renal function?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urea is transported by urea transport proteins (UT-A) by primary active transport

 

  • Urea is transported by urea transport proteins (UT-A) by primary active transport 
  • False because UT-A transporters mediate facilitated diffusion, not primary active transport.
  • Urea movement is passive, concentration-gradient driven, though facilitated by specific urea transporters.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. A high-protein diet increases the kidneys’ ability to concentrate urine:  More protein → more urea generated → higher medullary osmotic gradient → better concentrating ability.

 

Option B. High vasopressin increases the urea deposition in the medullary interstitium:  Vasopressin (ADH) upregulates urea transporters (UT-A1, UT-A3) in the inner medullary collecting duct, promoting urea reabsorption → raises medullary interstitial osmolarity.

 

Option D. Helpful in creation of counter-current mechanism: 

Urea recycling between collecting ducts and loop of Henle maintains the medullary osmotic gradient essential for water reabsorption.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Urea is transported by urea transport proteins (UT-A) by primary active transport

questions.text: Which of the following represents dark stained areas on a karyotype?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heterochromatin

 

Heterochromatin represents the darkly stained regions on a karyotype when chromosomes are stained with Giemsa dye (G-banding). These regions are tightly packed, transcriptionally inactive, and contain AT-rich DNA sequences. They replicate late during the S phase and are commonly found near centromeres and telomeres, serving structural and regulatory roles rather than active gene expression.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for recurrent vomiting that began 5 hours ago. He describes the vomitus as bloody and containing black specks. He drinks 10-12 beers daily and has not seen a physician in 15 years. He appears pale. Physical examination shows decreased radial pulses, delayed capillary refill, multiple spider angiomata, and a distended abdomen. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. Which of the following is most likely decreased in this patient in response to his hematemesis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Carotid baroreceptor firing activity

questions.text: Oral digoxin is being given to a 65-year-old male as a maintenance dose. A target plasma concentration of 0.70 ng/ mL is decided upon. The digoxin clearance for this particular individual is calculated as 60 mL/min. Knowing that the oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70%, what is the dosing rate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 60 ng/min 

 

We use the formula for maintenance dosing rate:

 

 

Step= Multiply concentration × clearance and divide by F

 

0.70 ng/mL×60 mL/min divided by 0.7=60 ng/min

questions.text: A patient has right upper limb BP of 160/85 mmHg and a left upper limb BP of 130/90 mmHg. He also has early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with these findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Supravalvular aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2 at 28 weeks is brought to the emergency after being found unconscious at home by her mother. She is disoriented on arrival and her BP is 180/110 mmHg and 4 + proteinuria. On arrival at the emergency, she has a tonic-clonic seizure which resolves with MgSO4 administration. Once the patient is stabilized, she undergoes caesarean delivery for fetal distress. Post-partum, the below MRI is done. What is the most likely finding on imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome

 

  • The case is classic for eclampsia: pregnant woman with hypertension, proteinuria, seizures.
  • The MRI shows bilateral symmetrical areas of hyperintensity in the posterior cerebral hemispheres (parieto-occipital regions), most characteristic of PRES.
  • PRES is associated with eclampsia and presents with headache, altered mental status, seizures, and visual disturbances. MRI usually shows vasogenic edema—seen as high signal in posterior regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdural hematoma, Option B. Parenchymal hemorrhage, Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Would show focal or diffuse hyperintensity in different locations, not typically as bilateral posterior edema.

choices.text: RBC mass increased, O2 saturation increased, EPO decreased
RBC mass increased, O2 saturation normal, EPO decreased
RBC mass increased, O2 saturation increased, EPO normal
RBC mass normal , O2 saturation normal, EPO increased

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with unbearable itching while taking a shower which has been present for many months. Physical examination shows the presence of facial plethora. Laboratory examination shows a hemoglobin of 20 g/dL. What would be the best match for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RBC mass increased, O2 saturation normal, EPO decreased

 

The clinical presentation of this 65-year-old male with facial plethora, a very high hemoglobin (20 g/dL), and itching (especially during showers) is suggestive of polycythemia vera (PV), a myeloproliferative disorder characterized by increased red blood cell mass.

 

Key features supporting this diagnosis:

 

  • Facial plethora is a classic sign of PV.
  • Pruritus, particularly after a hot shower, is a characteristic symptom of PV.
  • Elevated hemoglobin reflects increased RBC mass.
  • In PV, erythropoietin (EPO) levels are typically decreased because the increased RBC production is independent of EPO stimulation.
  • Oxygen saturation is usually normal, as PV is not caused by hypoxia.

 

Therefore, the best match is:

 

B) RBC mass increased, O2 saturation normal, EPO decreased

 

This matches the provided answer and fits the clinical and laboratory findings perfectly.

questions.text:
What would be seen if the central part of the cord was involved? 

 

  1. LMN lesion of trunk and UMN of lower limbs.
  2. UMN lesion of trunk and LMN of lower limbs.
  3. Bladder and bowel involvement.
  4. Posterior tract involvement.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

  •  Central cord lesions typically damage gray matter at the level of the lesion → LMN signs at that level (eg, trunk/upper limb weakness) and may also compress descending tracts → UMN signs in lower limbs. As the lesion progresses centrally, bladder & bowel involvement is common.

 

1 (LMN trunk + UMN lower limbs): Correct, due to segmental LMN loss and long tract UMN involvement.


3 (Bladder and bowel involvement): Correct, central cord compression can disrupt autonomic pathways.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

2 (UMN trunk + LMN lower limbs): Not seen; UMN signs don’t occur at the lesion level.

4 (Posterior tract involvement): Typically spared in central lesions until very advanced, so not a defining feature.

Increased lipolysis of bile acid bound cholesterol

questions.text: A patient with hypercholesterolemia is advised to take colesevelam. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Binding of bile acid in the intestine

questions.text: A patient 35-year-old male patient came with sudden onset palpitations. ECG is shown below, with a heart rate of 160 bpm. His BP is 102/78 mmHg. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Carotid sinus massage

choices.text: Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction
Fall of oxygen saturation triggers waking episodes at night

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to OPD with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness, and his wife also complains that he snores a lot at night during sleep. Which of the following is incorrect regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction

 

In obstructive sleep apnea, decreased tone (not increased) of pharyngeal muscles worsens airway obstruction during sleep. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Fall of oxygen saturation triggers waking episodes at night: Correct; hypoxia causes arousals to restore airflow. 

 

Option C. Episodes of apnea increase work of breathing: True; repeated apneas increase respiratory effort. 

 

Option C. PaO2 is normal during the day: Daytime oxygen levels often normalize despite nocturnal hypoxemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with fever, cough, and tenacious white sputum. Which of the following should be used for treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syrup Bromhexine

 

Bromhexine is a mucolytic agent that helps liquefy thick sputum by breaking down mucus, improving clearance. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Syrup Dextromethorphan with bromhexine: Combining an antitussive with a mucolytic is less appropriate for productive cough. 

 

Option B. Syrup Codeine: An antitussive not recommended with productive cough due to sputum retention risk. 

 

Option C. Syrup Dextromethorphan: Suppresses cough reflex; not ideal when sputum clearance is needed.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-D, 3-C, 4-B

 

  1. Swan neck deformity with activation of caspase-1, 4, and release of IL-1β in synovial fluid: Pyroptosis (A) (A form of inflammatory programmed cell death involving caspase-1 and IL-1β release)
  2. Dysregulation of glutathione peroxidase 4 and increased lipid peroxidation in a chemo-resistant breast tumor: Ferroptosis (D) (Iron-dependent lipid peroxidation-mediated cell death regulated by glutathione peroxidase 4)
  3. Radiation induced activation of caspase 9 and 3: Apoptosis (C) (Mitochondrial intrinsic pathway caspase cascade in regulated cell death)
  4. In sepsis, TNF-alpha mediated activation of receptor-interacting protein kinase 1 disrupts plasma membrane integrity causing cell swelling: Necroptosis (B)(A programmed necrosis pathway involving receptor interacting protein kinases) note that Necroptosis is CasPase INDEPENDENT

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with box car nuclei seen on histopathological examination of the myocytes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertensive cardiomyopathy 

 

  • The image shows "boxcar nuclei"—enlarged, rectangular, polygonal nuclei seen in cardiac myocytes.
  • Boxcar nuclei are typically found in ventricular myocytes exposed to chronic pressure overload, most commonly due to systemic hypertension (hypertensive cardiomyopathy).
  • Chronic hypertension leads to left ventricular hypertrophy, with characteristic nuclear enlargement and hyperchromasia (boxcar appearance) as myocytes hypertrophy to compensate for increased afterload.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restrictive cardiomyopathy and Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: May show different histopathological changes, but boxcar nuclei are not characteristic.

 

Option D. Subendocardial ischemia: Does not typically cause boxcar nuclei.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute exacerbation of COPD develops a sudden onset of palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. His BP is 90/60 mm Hg. What is the next step?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Verapamil

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is evaluated for persistent lower back pain and fatigue. Laboratory testing shows anemia and renal dysfunction. Serum electrophoresis of the serum proteins is shown below. A medication that blocks cellular proteasome action is administered. This treatment is most likely to cause which of the following effects on the abnormal cells?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Increased apoptosis

questions.text: A sugarcane farmer presents with dyspnea and cough for the last 3 weeks. HRCT shows bilateral ground glass opacities and centrilobular nodules. Lung biopsy shows poorly formed noncaseating granulomas. BAL CD4: CD8 ratio is 2:1. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

questions.text: A manufacturer substitutes a drug partly by another drug and doesn’t add it in the label. What is this type of drug called?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spurious drug

 

A drug is termed spurious if it is wholly or partly substituted by another drug or substance and not labeled accordingly.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Misbranded drug: A drug with false/misleading claims on label/packaging (not about substitution).


Option B. Adulterated drug: A drug prepared under unhygienic/contaminated conditions or containing harmful/toxic substances.


Option C. Unethical drug: Drugs promoted/marketed in a manner violating medical ethics, not related to substitution.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Tesamorelin is used in treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy
  2. Mecasermin is a recombinant form of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1).
  3. Leptin resistance leads to obesity.
  4. Oxygen-sensitive potassium (K+) channels are present in peripheral chemoreceptors.
questions.solution: Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

questions.text: The posture shown in image is seen in :
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper pons damage

 

The posture shown in the image is decerebrate rigidity/decerebrate posturing, characterized by extension and pronation of the arms, extended legs, and plantar flexed feet.

 

Key Association

 

  • Decerebrate posture indicates damage to the upper pons or lower midbrain, but classically it is seen in lesions affecting the upper pons

 

Decerebrate posture is a result of lesions below the red nucleus (in the upper pons or lower midbrain), leading to extensor posturing.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Upper pons hyperactivity: Hyperactivity is not the cause; rather, it’s upper pons damage.

 

Option B. Upper midbrain hyperactivity: Incorrect, hyperactivity isn’t relevant.

 

Option D. Upper midbrain damage: Would lead to decorticate posturing, not decerebrate.

questions.text: A 5 year old patient presents to the OPD with dysphagia, dysarthria, and dysphonia. On examination, brisk jaw jerk is seen. What is the possible localisation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corticobulbar tracts 

 

The clinical features—dysphagia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and a brisk jaw jerk—localize the lesion to the corticobulbar tracts.

 

Controls muscles innervated by cranial nerves; UMN lesion leads to pseudobulbar symptoms and brisk jaw jerk.

 

Case Analysis

 

  • Dysphagia, dysarthria, dysphonia: Indicate dysfunction of cranial nerves supplied by the bulbar region (IX, X, XII) and are signs of pseudobulbar palsy.
  • Brisk jaw jerk: This is an exaggerated deep tendon reflex, suggesting involvement of upper motor neurons innervating the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), typically via the corticobulbar tract.
  • Corticobulbar tract lesions commonly produce pseudobulbar symptoms and hyperactive jaw jerk.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Corticospinal tracts: Involved in limb motor control; would result in spasticity and brisk limb reflexes, not bulbar symptoms.

 

Option C. Mesencephalic trigeminal nucleus: Associated with jaw position/proprioception, not jaw jerk and bulbar palsy.

 

Option D. V3 nerve: Lesion would cause LMN signs like jaw deviation, not brisk jaw jerk or bulbar signs.

questions.text: A 65 year old patient has normal fluency and repetition of speech but impaired naming and comprehension. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transcortical sensory aphasia

 

The clinical presentation—normal fluency and repetition but impaired naming and comprehension—is characteristic of transcortical sensory aphasia.

 

  • Transcortical sensory aphasia:
    • Fluent speech
    • Good repetition
    • Poor comprehension and naming

choices.text: Vascular hydrostatic pressure increased, Oncotic pressure increased, lymphatic flow normal
Vascular hydrostatic pressure normal, Oncotic pressure normal, lymphatic flow decreased
Vascular hydrostatic pressure increased, Oncotic pressure normal, lymphatic flow increased
Vascular hydrostatic pressure normal, Oncotic pressure decreased, lymphatic flow increased

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD due to worsening dyspnea on exertion for the past 3 months. The patient has had a nonproductive cough but no chest pain, fever, or chills. He was diagnosed with hypertension several years ago but takes no medications. Physical examination shows bilateral inspiratory crackles as well as dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds at the right lung base. Chest x-ray reveals a right-sided pleural effusion. Which of the following pleuropulmonary changes are most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vascular hydrostatic pressure increased, Oncotic pressure normal, lymphatic flow increased

 

Increased hydrostatic pressure from conditions like heart failure causes pleural effusion with normal oncotic pressure and compensatory increased lymphatic flow. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Vascular hydrostatic pressure increased, Oncotic pressure increased, lymphatic flow normal: Uncommon combination; oncotic pressure typically decreases in fluid accumulation. 

 

Option B. Vascular hydrostatic pressure normal, Oncotic pressure normal, lymphatic flow decreased: Decreased lymphatic flow typically causes chylous or malignant effusions, not this scenario. 

 

Option D. Vascular hydrostatic pressure normal, Oncotic pressure decreased, lymphatic flow increased: Seen in hypoalbuminemia, but normally oncotic pressure is maintained in hypertension-related effusions.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the effects of Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency? 

 

  1. Decrease in reduced glutathione
  2. Decreased NADPH
  3. Decreased lipid peroxidation
  4. Increased autofluorescence
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1 & 2 are correct.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting and seizures. On examination blood pressure is 220/110 mm Hg. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for managing his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV Labetalol

 

  • The patient has a hypertensive emergency with signs of hypertensive encephalopathy (headache, confusion, seizures, visual disturbances) and very high blood pressure (220/110 mm Hg).
  • In hypertensive emergencies, intravenous antihypertensives with rapid onset but controlled lowering of blood pressure are required.
  • IV Labetalol is a commonly used, effective agent that lowers BP quickly without significant cerebral blood flow reduction.
  • Oral agents like nifedipine or nicardipine capsules are too slow or inappropriate for emergencies.
  • IV nitroglycerin mainly dilates veins and is generally used for acute coronary syndrome or pulmonary edema, not primary hypertensive encephalopathy.

 

Thus, IV labetalol is the most appropriate choice.The correct answer is A. Cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady who is 2 weeks postpartum presents with headache, and acute episode of generalized seizures. The contrast-enhanced CT of the head is shown below. What is the drug of choice for the acute management of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LMWH 

 

The drug of choice for acute management of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) is low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

 

Standard of care for CVST acute management.

 

Case Analysis

 

  • History: Postpartum, headache, seizures—classic risk factors and presentation for CVST.
  • Image: Contrast-enhanced CT shows a filling defect. 
  • Treatment: Acute management requires anticoagulation, with LMWH as the preferred agent to prevent clot propagation and facilitate recanalization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Labetalol: Used in acute hypertension, not CVST.

 

Option B. IV MgSO4: First-line for eclampsia, not indicated here.

 

Option D. Aspirin: Not indicated for acute CVST; anticoagulation is preferred

questions.text: All of the following parameters are true for anemia of chronic disease except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Increased ferroportin

questions.text: An 18-year-old man, who was recently started on risperidone therapy for schizophrenia, comes to the office due to involuntary deviation of his head. There is palpable tightening of the right sternocleidomastoid muscle. It is determined that the patient is experiencing a medication-induced dystonic reaction due to motor neuron hyperactivity. The persistent myocyte stimulation causes a substance to be released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. This substance most likely binds to which of the following proteins to cause this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Troponin

 

In acute dystonia caused by antipsychotics (eg, risperidone), excessive stimulation of motor neurons leads to sustained depolarization at the neuromuscular junction.

 

This causes continuous release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum via ryanodine receptors.

 

Calcium then binds to troponin C, which moves tropomyosin away from actin’s myosin-binding sites, allowing persistent actin-myosin cross-bridge cycling → sustained muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Actin: Structural protein of thin filaments, but calcium does not bind directly to it.
 

Option B. Myosin: Thick filament motor protein that binds actin once tropomyosin shifts, but it is not the calcium-binding site.
 

Option C. Tropomyosin: Covers myosin-binding sites on actin; calcium binding does not occur here, but calcium binding to troponin moves tropomyosin.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, nausea, and dizziness for the past few weeks. His investigations reveal hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. He also complains of skin changes as seen in the image below (A before 3 yrs; B,C,D at presentation). Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Insulin resistance

 

The clinical images (C and D) show hyperpigmentation and thickened skin over the hands and palms, which is characteristic of acanthosis nigricans. This skin finding is most commonly associated with insulin resistance, seen in conditions such as type 2 diabetes mellitus and obesity.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Does not cause characteristic acanthosis nigricans.

 

Option C. Decreased androgen: Not associated with the shown skin changes.

 

Option D. Decreased cortisol: Usually leads to diffuse hyperpigmentation (Addison's disease) but not the specific thickening seen here.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has developed persistent food-seeking behavior over the past few months. His mother initially thought that the boy was undergoing a growth spurt, but despite how much she fed him he never seemed satisfied. The patient has also started complaining of a headache and nausea in the morning. His physical examination is significant for BMI of 32 kg/m2. This patient's food-seeking behavior could be explained by a lesion causing hyperactivity of which hypothalamic nucleus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral

 

The patient's persistent food-seeking behavior and obesity indicate hyperactivity or loss of inhibition of the lateral hypothalamic nucleus, which is known as the "feeding center".

 

  • The lateral hypothalamic nucleus (LHN) stimulates hunger and feeding behavior.
  • Lesions in this area cause loss of hunger (aphagia), while hyperactivity or stimulation leads to increased feeding and obesity.
  • The patient's symptoms of persistent hunger despite eating and increased BMI are consistent with lateral hypothalamic nucleus hyperactivity or an abnormal lesion causing its stimulation.
  • Associated signs of increased intracranial pressure (morning headache, nausea) suggest a possible hypothalamic tumor or mass effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior nucleus: Mainly involved in heat loss and parasympathetic (cooling) activities.

 

Option C. Supraoptic nucleus: Produces ADH and oxytocin, involved in water balance, not feeding

 

Option D. Ventromedial nucleus: The "satiety center"; lesions here cause hyperphagia and obesity, but hyperactivity results in anorexia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of breathlessness on walking a few metres. He adds that he has an uncomfortable awareness of his heartbeat, especially on lying down. Examination reveals widened pulse pressure and pulsating uvula. Which of the following would be the most likely auscultatory finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Austin Flint murmur

 

  • The patient’s symptoms of breathlessness on exertion, widened pulse pressure, and pulsating uvula are classic signs of aortic regurgitation (AR).
  • The Austin Flint murmur is a low-pitched, mid-to-late diastolic rumbling murmur heard best at the cardiac apex in AR.
  • It is produced by the regurgitant jet from the aorta impinging on the anterior mitral leaflet, causing functional mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carey Coombs murmur: Mid-diastolic murmur due to mitral valve inflammation in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Gallavardin phenomenon: Murmur of aortic stenosis radiating to the apex, sometimes mistaken for mitral regurgitation.

 

Option D. Graham Steel murmur: A high-pitched, early diastolic murmur heard in pulmonary regurgitation due to pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Two antineoplastic drugs are shown to inhibit intracellular thymidylate formation. The chemotherapeutic effect of drug X can be overcome by Ns-formyl-tetrahydrofolate supplementation, but that of drug Y is not affected. The drugs described in this scenario are most likely which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. D. X: Methotrexate Y: Fluorouracil

Identify the correct statements

 

  1. Capillaries have maximum cross-sectional area.
  2. Universal plasma donor is AB negative
  3. Calcium carbonate can lead to milk-alkali syndrome
  4. Resistant hypertension BP > 140/90 mmHg with two or more anti hypertensives, one being diuretic
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

questions.solution: Ans. B)

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

  1. Leptin serves a permissive role in puberty
  2. Weber-Fechner law describes the relationship between the magnitude of a physical stimulus and the perceived intensity 
  3. Golgi complex is located in supranuclear cytoplasm in serous acinar cells. 
  4. Ganglion cells are the third-order neurons in the optic pathway.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

All statements are correct 

 

  • 1. Leptin serves a permissive role in puberty → Leptin signals adequate energy stores to the hypothalamus, allowing pubertal onset.
  • 2. Weber-Fechner law → Describes the logarithmic relationship between stimulus magnitude and perceived intensity.
  • 3. Golgi complex in serous acinar cells → Located in the supranuclear cytoplasm, involved in protein processing and secretion.
  • 4. Ganglion cells as third-order neurons → In the optic pathway, ganglion cells transmit visual signals from the retina to the lateral geniculate nucleus.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed the septal anterior motion of mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and which of the following are true regarding the management? 

 

Management

  1. Beta-blockers are given
  2. Beta-blockers are contraindicated
  3. ICD is indicated
  4. ICD is contraindicated

 

Clinical findings

  1. Pulsus bisferiens
  2. Pulsus alternans
  3. Ejection systolic murmur
  4. Murmur increases on standing
  5. Murmur decreases on standing
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 3; a, c, d

 

  • The clinical scenario describes hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM):
    • ECG shows T-wave inversions in V5, V6.
    • 2D Echo shows systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve.
    • The patient collapsed while playing sports, raising concern for arrhythmias or sudden cardiac death risk.

 

Clinical findings in HCM:

 

  • Pulsus bisferiens (a double-peaked carotid pulse) is classic.
  • Ejection systolic murmur due to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.
  • The murmur increases on standing (due to decreased preload, increased obstruction).

 

Management:

 

  • Beta-blockers are given to reduce heart rate and improve diastolic filling.
  • ICD (implantable cardioverter defibrillator) is indicated for sudden cardiac death prevention in high-risk patients with HCM.

 

Other options are incorrect because beta-blockers are not contraindicated in HCM, and ICD is indicated, not contraindicated.

 

Thus, the appropriate combination is 1 & 3; a, c, d.

choices.text: Incomplete penetrance of homozygotic HFE mutations

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman dies of congestive heart failure. Autopsy shows a dilated heart with brownish pigmentation of the myocardium. Light microscopy of her liver after Prussian blue staining is shown in the image below. The patient's brother died of profuse upper gastrointestinal bleeding at age 43. Assuming this patient's disorder is hereditary, which of the following most likely contributed to the delayed onset of her disease compared to her brother?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Premenopausal menstrual bleeding

 

  • This patient had Hereditary Hemochromatosis (HFE gene mutation) causing iron overload (brown myocardium, Prussian blue–positive iron in liver).
  • In men, iron accumulation begins earlier because they do not have a mechanism of iron loss.
  • In women, menstrual blood loss before menopause delays the onset of clinical disease (cardiomyopathy, cirrhosis, diabetes).
  • Hence, the brother developed complications earlier, while this woman manifested later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heterozygosity for HFE gene mutation: Would not cause severe disease; homozygosity is usually required.

 

Option B. High-dose vitamin C intake: Accelerates iron absorption, but would worsen rather than delay disease.

 

Option C. Incomplete penetrance of homozygotic HFE mutations: Explains variability in expression but not consistent sex-related delay.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of cellular events of inflammation?

 

  1. Selectin 
  2. ICAM-1
  3. CD31
  4. IL-8
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

  • 1. Selectin: Mediates rolling of leukocytes along the endothelium.
  • 2. ICAM-1: Facilitates firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelial surface.
  • 3. CD31: Involved in diapedesis, allowing leukocytes to migrate through the endothelium.
  • 4. IL-8: Acts as a chemotactic factor, guiding leukocytes to the site of inflammation.
